Title: Type 1 conditional
References: ALEXANDER, L. G.: Longman English Grammar. 20th edition. New York : Longman publishing, 2003. 351 p.
Content:
First conditional is used to describe what will or what won't happen if we think a future event is probable.

   The most commonly used form is: If  +  present simple  +  will.

(we can use shall, can, may instead of will)

   Imagine: You are at home. You plan to play tennis this afternoon. But there are some clouds in the sky. Imagine that it rains. What will you do?

examples:

- If it rains, I will stay home.

- If the weather is nice, many people will go to the beach.

- If I have a headache, I will take an aspirin. 

- If I can afford it, I will buy it.
